page.title: 12Berwick St.James Water Mill
page.content: {The Mill,}a brick and flint building astride the river Till, a tributary of the river Wylye, was built by local craftsmen in about 1810. An undershot water wheel originally powered cake- and root- cutting machinery and corn grinding stones within the Mill, and butter and cheese making machinery in an adjoining house. Today, that same wheel powers a pump drawing water from a 60-foot bore hole, and provides water for an 800 acre farm. The building is of three floors, the ground floor housing the wheel and associated hatches for controlling water levels. On old maps the building is described as the Bean Mill, suggesting that pulses were grown for animal feeds.
